question.text: A particle of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kg</mi></math> is initially at rest in the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane at a point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>l</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>. The particle is accelerated at time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> with a constant acceleration <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> along the positive <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. Its angular momentum and torque with respect to the origin, in SI units, are represented by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mi>L</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> and  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mi>τ</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>, respectively. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> are unit vectors along the positive <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>z</mi></math>-directions, respectively. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>×</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">j</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> then which of the following statement(s) is (are) correct?

options.text: The particle arrives at the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> at time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>τ</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> when the particle passes through the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>L</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> when the particle passes through the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover accent="true"><mi>τ</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math> when the particle passes through the point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>.

solution.text:
At t=2 s:

displacement along +X axis

=12×10×t2

=12×10×4=20 m

Hence, particle arrives at 10,-1

At x=l, y=−h,

τ→=r→×F→

=10i^−j^×0.2×10i^=2k^ N m

L→=r→×p→=10i^−j^×0.2×vi^

and vat t=2s=0+10×2=20 m s-1

∴  L→=10i^−j^×4i^=4k^ N m s

At x=0,y=−h:

r→=0i^−j^

F→=2i^

∴  τ→=r→×F→=2k^ N m
